items.synopsis: The construction industry insolvency crisis is sweeping the nation, and it's devastating for both consumers and builders. So what can be done about it?

image.altText: Philip Lowe wearing glasses and a suit sits at a table and speaks.

items.synopsis: There is one issue that stands head and shoulders above the rest as Philip Lowe's greatest threat in the battle to control inflation, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: The property market rebound could see us heading into uncharted and dangerous territory

image.altText: A woman outside a court building in handcuffs.

items.synopsis: Crystal Leanne Hanley is granted home detention bail to clean up her SA Housing rental property, which the prosecutor has described as being "unsuitable for human habitation".

title.children: Woman charged with daughter's manslaughter granted home detention bail to clean up 'squalid' rental

image.altText: a woman looking at the camera and smiling

items.synopsis: Extensive scientific and medical evidence proved to be key to setting Kathleen Folbigg free, 20 years after she was convicted of killing her four children.

title.children: The science that unlocked a rare genetic mutation in the Folbiggs — and set Kathleen free

image.altText: Thick fog blankets an airstrip where a light plane is parked next to a wind-sock.

items.synopsis: William Creek tourism operator Trevor Wright told the ABC he had only seen such thick fog on a handful of occasions, which the BOM says has been caused by an unusual amount of moisture in northern SA.

title.children: Thick fog covers large parts of South Australia's outback

image.altText: a man wearing a suit standing in front of video and photo cameras

items.synopsis: The full findings into the Victoria Cross recipient's unsuccessful defamation lawsuit are now public, and outline Justice Anthony Besanko's reasoning. Here are five findings you may have missed.

title.children: Five key findings from the Ben Roberts-Smith judgement

image.altText: Ben Roberts-Smith receives Victoria Cross

items.synopsis: The Ben Roberts-Smith verdict has reopened the wounds of a shameful period of Australian military history that demonstrates how the leadership of the ADF has failed, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: The Ben Roberts-Smith verdict has shocked the military. But why didn't its leaders act sooner?

image.altText: woman looks lovingly at her chihuahua puppy who fits in her hand

items.synopsis: New laws require a landlord to give a reason for refusing a tenant's request to have a pet, like if the animal is dangerous or the property is too small for it.

title.children: When Kelly was told she couldn't have a dog in her rental property, she wanted to know why

image.altText: On the left, an apartment window near a balcony with light streaming in. On the right, a photo of the same room but darker.

items.synopsis: Evidence is growing about the importance of being exposed to enough natural light, but what rights do residents have to protect their access to it?

title.children: Construction turned Huw's bright apartment into a 'dungeon'. There was nothing he could do

image.altText: Ada under a blanket on the couch looking miserable, while a cat sits on her lap.

items.synopsis: Healthcare workers have warned the flu season has arrived early this year and is hitting young kids harder than usual.

title.children: From 32,000 to 68,000 cases in five weeks: Flu season is spiking early. Doctors say children could be at risk

image.altText: An ad for an Adelaide nightclub featuring a fake polar bear in a bra.

items.synopsis: An Adelaide nightclub has apologised for a social media campaign, condemned as "misogynistic", in which a free drinks offer was extended to patrons based on their breast sizes.

title.children: Bar that encouraged women to take off bras for free drinks apologises

image.altText: Three kids dig holes with shovels at the bottom of a mound of dirt.

items.synopsis: This Bougainville community is living on a literal goldmine, but some residents say that despite it being abandoned for decades, it poses a risk to their environment and human rights.

title.children: This Bougainville community lives on a literal goldmine. They call themselves 'the unfortunate ones'

image.altText: Business people walk outside the Reserve Bank of Australia.

items.synopsis: Economists are tipping interest rates will rise for the 12th time in a year when the RBA announces its latest decision this afternoon, while Apple shares have set a new record high in the wake of the company showcasing its new products. Follow live.

title.children: RBA interest rate decision looms, Apple shares reach record high, ASX to slip

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: With OPEC oil producing nations announcing production cuts, there are some concerns a decrease in supply could push up global inflation. OPEC's decision extended an agreement on crude supply restrictions from this year into 2024, with Saudi Arabia announcing production cuts of 1 million barrels per day, amid frustration at falling oil prices. But senior market analyst at OANDA, Craig Erlam told RN Breakfast he doesn't believe it will drive up inflation globally as the situation currently stands. "It doesn't [affect us] I don't think at this point in time, and the reason is because the markets have largely shrugged it off, " he said. "Like I say, the price of a barrel of oil at times last year was well above $100 a barrel. If we look back at Q2 last year, you can see that a price of barrel of oil, I think at one point even spiked around $130, although it didn't really stay there for very long. "Going in between, say the fourth quarter of last year and the end of the first quarter this year it's trading between $80 and $90 a barrel. "Today it's $78 in the aftermath, $77-76 in the aftermath of this announcement, so we should still be seeing disinflation in the oil prices compared to a year ago, so it still should be a disinflationary force. "But if this is met with other actions by OPEC plus over the coming months that may change."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Cut in oil production won't add to global inflation, analyst says

children.content: With OPEC oil producing nations announcing production cuts, there are some concerns a decrease in supply could push up global inflation.
OPEC's decision extended an agreement on crude supply restrictions from this year into 2024, with
Saudi Arabia
announcing production cuts of 1 million barrels per day
, amid frustration at falling oil prices.
But senior market analyst at OANDA,
Craig Erlam
told
RN Breakfast
he doesn't believe it will drive up inflation globally as the situation currently stands.
"It doesn't [affect us] I don't think at this point in time, and the reason is because
the markets have largely shrugged it off,
" he said.

"Like I say, the price of a barrel of oil at times last year was well above $100 a barrel. If we look back at Q2 last year, you can see that a price of barrel of oil, I think at one point even spiked around $130, although it didn't really stay there for very long.
"Going in between, say the fourth quarter of last year and the end of the first quarter this year it's trading between $80 and $90 a barrel.
"Today it's $78 in the aftermath, $77-76 in the aftermath of this announcement, so we should still be seeing disinflation in the oil prices compared to a year ago, so
it still should be a disinflationary force
"But if this is met with other actions by OPEC plus over the coming months that may change."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you've been closely following the political spin on the federal budget last month, you'll know that the Coalition's major concern is that it is making inflation worse. That was reiterated by Shadow Treasurer Angus Taylor was on News Breakfast earlier this morning, who said the government can no longer blame global events like the war in Ukraine for inflation, and it was the government's fault it was still so high. Host Lisa Millar put that line of thinking to Assistant Treasurer Stephen Jones, who maintains that it would not add to inflation and make the current situation worse. Here's what he said in response: "Look, you can just contrast what Angus Taylor is saying with the words of the Reserve Bank governor himself, who has said that the budget that the government  handed down three weeks ago was not inflationary. "I think I prefer the Reserve Bank governor's opinion over Angus Taylor's opinion when it comes to inflation and  interest rates. That's the one that matters."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Assistant Treasurer adamant federal budget 'not inflationary'

children.content: If you've been closely following the political spin on the federal budget last month, you'll know that the Coalition's major concern is that it is making inflation worse.
That was reiterated by Shadow Treasurer
Angus Taylor
was on
News Breakfast
earlier this morning, who said the government can no longer blame global events like the war in Ukraine for inflation, and it was the government's fault it was still so high.
Host
Lisa Millar
put that line of thinking to
Assistant Treasurer Stephen Jones
, who maintains that it would not add to inflation and make the current situation worse.
Here's what he said in response:
"Look, you can just contrast what Angus Taylor is saying with the words of the Reserve Bank governor himself, who has said that the budget that the government  handed down three weeks ago was
not inflationary
"I think I prefer the Reserve Bank governor's opinion over Angus Taylor's opinion when it comes to inflation and  interest rates. That's the one that matters."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Assistant Treasurer and Financial Services Minister Stephen Jones was on News Breakfast a short time ago talking about scams ahead of tax time, before he was asked about today's RBA decision. He said he recognises a potential increase would cause pain for households, which is why the government was focused on providing relief in its budget last month. "We know that households and businesses are doing it tough. Cost of living is, you know, a big impact on every  household around the country," he said. "It's why the Government in its budget was trying to walk that very fine line between providing some targeted relief, but not making the inflation situation worse. "The Reserve Bank  will make its decision, operates  independently from the government, it will make its decision this morning."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Government walking 'fine line' to provide cost of living relief

children.content: Assistant Treasurer and Financial Services Minister
Stephen Jones
was on News Breakfast a short time ago talking about scams ahead of tax time, before he was asked about today's RBA decision.
He said he recognises a potential increase would cause pain for households, which is why the government was focused on providing relief in its budget last month.
"We know that households and businesses are doing it tough. Cost of living is, you know, a big impact on every  household around the country," he said.
"It's why the Government in its budget was trying to walk that very fine line between providing some targeted relief, but not making the inflation situation worse.
"The Reserve Bank  will make its decision, operates  independently from the government, it will make its decision this morning."

props.alt: Stephen Jones wearing a blue shirt and red tie with glasses sits in front of a backdrop of Parliament House.

children.content: Assistant Treasurer Stephen Jones.
(News Breakfast)

title.children: Long road to freedom: Kathleen Folbigg's tragic life started well before her babies died

title.children: No survivors found after plane that flew over US capital and led to fighter jet scramble crashes in Virginia

image.altText: A woman smiles as she puts food inside a cage trap.
